{{Infobox company | name = RONA | logo = RONA.jpg | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = 1892 | founder = [[Jozef Schreiber]] | location = [[Lednické Rovne]], [[Slovakia]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = | industry = Glass [[manufacturer]], production of drinking glasses of lead-free crystal,<ref> {{cite web | title= COUNCIL DIRECTIVE of 15 December 1969 on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to crystal glass | url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/SK/ALL/?uri=CELEX%3A31969L0493 | website = eur-lex.europa.eu | accessdate= 6 February 2017 }}</ref> clear and decorated | products = [[Household goods]], drinking glass for households and professional use in [[gastronomy]], aerospace and ship [[catering]] | certifications = | revenue = [[Euro|€]]62 millions(2015)<ref name="RONA: 2015 Annual Report"> {{cite journal | author1 = | title = RONA: Annual Report 2015 | url = http://www.rona.sk/data/files/133_rona_annual_report_2015.pdf | website = | date = Jan 31, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="Register of Financial Statements"> {{cite journal | author1 = | title = RONA: Register of Financial Statements | url = http://www.registeruz.sk/cruz-public/domain/accountingentity/show/175209 | website = | date = Jan 31, 2017 }}</ref> | subsid = | homepage = {{url|http://www.rona.sk}} }}
'''RONA a.s.''' (distribution under RONA brand) is a Slovak drinking glass manufacturer, established in [[Lednické Rovne]], Slovakia, in 1892. The name RONA comes from the former naming of the village ‘‘Lednicz Rone’’.<ref name="sme"> {{cite news | last = Németh | first = Jana | title = Keď je sklo ako med | newspaper = SME | location = Bratislava, Slovakia | pages = | language = | publisher = sme.sk | date = | url = http://kultura.sme.sk/c/7257551/ked-je-sklo-ako-med.html | access-date = 27 June 2014 }}</ref> The company manufactures unleaded drinking glasses, known as [[crystal glass]]. 96% of production is exported and is available in more than 80 countries worldwide. The yearly production of the company exceeds 60 million pieces (2016).<ref name="RONA: 2015 Annual Report"/><ref name="Register of Financial Statements"/> Product segments include households, the gastronomy business, aerospace, and ship catering. [[File:Rainbow_Room,_Rockefeller_Center,_NYC_sklo_RONA.jpg|thumb|left|RONA Glass in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, NYC, 2015.]] Products of the company can be found at [[Buckingham palace]] and the [[White House]]. RONA created also a gift set for the football club [[Manchester United]] designed for fan shops in 2006. At the turn of 2008 and 2009, the company created and manufactured sets for fans of [[FC Barcelona]], composed of [[stemware]] for champagne, red and white wines and carafes. The glass from Lednické Rovne can be found in the New York Rockefeller center's [[Rainbow Room]], and in luxury hotels in [[Dubai]] and [[Las Vegas]]. The glass from the RONA company is supplied to airlines including: [[Emirates (airline)|Emirates]], [[Qatar Airways]], [[Etihad]], [[KLM]], and [[American Airlines]].<ref name="život"> {{cite news | last = Fuknová | first = Marcela | title = Krehké víťazstva | newspaper = ŽIVOT | location = Bratislava, Slovakia | pages = 46–48 | language = slovak | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.rona.sk/data/files/132_clanok-v-zivote0001.pdf | access-date = 21 June 2016 }}</ref> Relief stemware set named Harmony was presented in an American sitcom from the world of young physicists, [[The Big Bang Theory]].
The main manufacturing programs of the [[glassworks]]: * An automatic manufacturing of the stemware with attached stem, stemware with pulled stem, large accessory pieces such as vases, bowls, carafes and other accessories * Handmade stemware, tumblers, vases, bowls, carafes and accessories * Glass (hand made and machine made) refinements by various [[glass decoration techniques]] ([[pantograph|pantograph etching]], [[cutting]], [[painting]], [[engraving]], [[spray painting|spraying]], [[screen printing]], [[tampoprint]], an automatic calibration by [[laser]]).
== History == === Founding=== [[File:Josef_Schreiber_1894.jpg|thumb|right|Jozef Schreiber: Founder of glassworks]] An entrepreneur Jozef Schreiber founded the company in 1892 as the last and the biggest glassworks of Vienna’s company [[Schreiber und Neffen]], who had the most modern equipment of the time.<ref name="dennikn.sk"> {{cite news | last = Pekárová | first = Adriena | title = Nápojová súprava, z ktorej by bolo potešenie piť | newspaper = | location = Slovakia | pages = | language = slovak | publisher = dennikn.sk | date = 26 November 2016 | url = https://dennikn.sk/305624/napojova-suprava-ktorej-by-potesenie-pit/ | access-date = 3 February 2017 }}</ref><ref name="aktuality.sk"> {{cite news | last = | first = | title = 124 rokov tradície a hrdosti: slovenskí sklári z Lednických Rovní | newspaper = | location = Slovakia | pages = | language = slovak | publisher = aktuality.sk | date = 5 September 2016 | url = https://www.aktuality.sk/clanok/368822/124-rokov-tradicie-a-hrdosti-slovenski-sklari-z-lednickych-rovni/ | access-date = 3 February 2017 }}</ref> The company in Lednické Rovne is the most successful Slovak glassworks and the only one left (2017).
It started by the manufacturing of [[flat glass]], later [[pressed glass]] under Kaiserkristall brand that the company established as the first in [[Austria-Hungary]]. This was popular at the turn of the century for price and the fact that it imitated products of luxury cut [[lead glass]]. The goods were sold under the name ’’Imperial Crystal’’.<ref name="history SME"> {{cite news | last = | first = | title = Letmý pohľad cez sklo z Lednických Rovní | newspaper = | location = Slovakia | pages = | language = slovak | publisher = sme.sk | date = 25 October 2002 | url = https://www.sme.sk/c/708467/letmy-pohlad-cez-sklo-z-lednickych-rovni.html | access-date = 3 February 2017 }}</ref><ref name="history HN"> {{cite news | last = | first = | title = Čaše z RONY | newspaper = | location = Slovakia | pages = | language = slovak | publisher = hnonline.sk | date = 26 March 2007 | url = https://hnporadna.hnonline.sk/podnikanie/196667-case-z-rony | access-date = 3 February 2017 }}</ref> Besides the pressed glass was manufactured hand blown glass under RONA Crystal brand focused on drinking glass and sets for hotels, medical institutions, cafes… as well as domestic glass for a household.
Besides clear glass, the glassworks is known for its decoration techniques such as cutting, engraving, [[guilloche]], painting, spraying, screen printing, tampoprint (an automatic calibration by laser), and pantograph technology. The company in Lednické Rovne established pantographs of English production as the first in Europe in 1896.<ref name="history SME"/><ref name="history HN"/> In the 1940s, the company cooperated in the development of decors with professional designers [[Vincent Hložník]] and [[Martin Benka]]. [[File:RONA pantograph.jpg|thumb|RONA pantograph]]
Archived collections show products from the beginning that were decorated, full-colour pieces, along with functional designs of clear, plain glass. These lines were developed by patenting of a new handmade technology. [[Pulled stem]], even more in 1956 than currently, is an indicator of glass products from Lednické Rovne.<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Poláčková | first1 = Dagmar | last2 = Büngerová | first2 = Vladimíra | title = Cheers! to design! : 120 years of the glass works in Lednické Rovne | publisher = Slovak National Gallery, Bratislava, Slovakia | year = 2012 | pages = 30 | isbn = 978-80-8059-168-7 }}</ref>
The history and production of the company was documented by many specialists in their publications; historians and publicists such as Jan Bárta, Ján Mondok, Eduard Toran, Igor Didov, Karol Hetteš, Jindra Bakošová, Agáta Žáčková, Jarmila Račeková and others. Likewise articles in special magazines such as [[Glasrevue]], Sklář a keramik, Sklárske rozhledy, Umení a remesla, [[Arte Regalo]]<ref name="Arte Regalo"> {{cite journal | author1 = | title = 125 AÑOS DE CREATIVIDAD | url = http://www.rona.sk/data/files/150_arte_regalo_255r.pdf | website = | date = Feb 8, 2017 }}</ref>(Spanish magazine), [[Tableware International]], [[Offrir International]], and [[Casastile]] (Italian magazine).
=== Chronology of development and organizational changes === The company over time has transitioned into and out of socialism, emerging in 1990 to become an exporter in 1992.
{| class="wikitable" |- | 1892 || Establishment of glassworks Schreiber and nephews (Schreiber und Neffen) by its owner and founder [[Joseph Schreiber]]. The glassworks starts with the production of flat glass and tableware pressed glass, but mainly focused on the production of drinking glasses and sets for wholesale customers (hotels, medical centers, cafeterias) under the brand name Rona Crystal. Glassworks is supplying their products to a number of major hotels, including the world-famous Hotel Sacher in [[Vienna]]. |- | 1897 || Sklené huty (Glassworks), joint stock company Vienna (Glashűttenwerke, Vormals J.Schreiber und Neffen, Aktiengesellschaft Wien) |- | start of the [[World War]] 2 || [[Stölzle Glass|Stőlzle Glasindustrie Aktiengesselschaft]] in Wien (belonging to concern Creditanstallt - Bank verein in Wien) |- | 18 February 1942 || Slovenské sklené huty (Slovak Glassworks), formerly Jozef Schreiber and Neffen, joint stock company with the registered office in Lednické Rovne - separation related to the establishment of the Slovak State |- | from 25 October 1945 (till [[nationalisation]]) || Slovenské sklené huty (Slovak Glassworks), under the national administration |- | 1946 (after nationalisation) || Slovenské sklárne, n.p. (Joint Glassworks, national enterprise) [[Lednické Rovne]] with the registered office in [[Bratislava]] |- | 1950 || Slovenské sklárne, n.p. (Joint Glassworks, national enterprise) [[Lednické Rovne]] |- | from 1 January 1962 || Spojené sklárne in Lednické Rovne made part of VHJ "Association of companies producing utility glass" in Nový Bor |- | from 1 January 1972 || Establishment of VHJ Tatrasklo with general directorate in Trnava incorporating five Slovak glassmaking companies |- | 1990 || Company as the first leaving GR Tatrasko - transformation period start |- | 1 April 1990 || Spojené sklárne, state enterprise Lednické Rovne |- | 1 May 1992 || Name change to joint stock company - LR Crystal, a.s. - its objective was to penetrate to foreign markets under the brand LR Crystal and later RONA Crystal, a.s. a Slovak exporter |- | 2 January 1996 - 25 Apríl 2000 || B.D.S., a.s. - commercial company exported 95% of its production produced by the production company LR Crystal, a.s. to abroad |- | 1996 || Established a foreign trade branch in [[Liberec]], [[Czech Republic]]. |- | 26 April 2000 - 30 December 2001 || RONA Trading, a.s. - created by the transition from the commercial company B.D.S., a.s. |- | 17 December 2001 - 31 December 2002 || RONA Crystal, a.s. - production company established by merger of LR Crystal, a.s. and RONA Trading, a.s. |- | 9 January 2002 || RONA, a.s. - commercial company |- | 1 January 2003 || RONA, a.s. - current business name of the company with the registered office in Lednické Rovne - established by the merger of RONA Crystal, a.s. and RONA, a.s.. It represents the group of organisations ensuring complex activities linked with the development, production and sales of utility glass and other activities. |- |}
=== Calendar of innovations === The development of glass production in Lednické Rovne went through many organizational changes, the company overcame many crisis periods of that time and the great program and focused production such as pressed glass, cylinders for lamps, technique and laboratory glass, light bulbs, feeding bottles… changed quite often and it gained the recognition as a producer mostly quality drinking glass at the beginning of 20th century. This program is a representative article of the company to the present when the proportion of hand made and machine production was changed as well as decoration glass. From the half of 60’s of the 20th century, the company focused mainly on a gradual introduction of machinery and automatic production of glass.
{| class="wikitable" |- | 1892 || Starting with the production of flat glass as well as the production focused on [[tableware]] pressed glass, but mainly focused on the production of drinking glass and sets for wholesale customers (hotels, medical centres, cafes). |- | 1896 || The pantograph purchased in England (the first English pantograph on the European continent) at that time was applied to obtain decorated items. Thin wall stemware with fine pantograph decoration becomes one of the hallmarks of glass from Lednické Rovne. The goblets were decorated by stylized vegetation motifs and later by geometric patterns of the Art Nouveau period. |- | 1902 || Introduction of guilloche decorating technique. |- | 1918 || Glassworks in Uhrovec was closed and the production was relocated regarding glass screens for lamps (cylinders for kerosene lamps), which have become significant production and export items. |- | 1956 || The technology of pulled stem was applied in the handmade production as the first in the world (designers Hološko-Taraba).<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Poláčková | first1 = Dagmar | last2 = Büngerová | first2 = Vladimíra | title = Cheers! to design! : 120 years of the glass works in Lednické Rovne | publisher = Slovak National Gallery, Bratislava, Slovakia | year = 2012 | pages = 21–22 | isbn = 978-80-8059-168-7 }}</ref> |- | until 1968 || Production of lamp bulbs, feeding bottles, and technical glass. |- | 1968 || The year of the start of transition from manual to automatic production. |- | 1981 || The first automatic line was put into operation for the production of mechanically formed goblets by blow-blow technology. |- | 1998 || The glass composition is changed to lead-free [[crystal glass]].<ref> {{cite web | title = COUNCIL DIRECTIVE of 15 December 1969 on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to crystal glass | url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/SK/ALL/?uri=CELEX%3A31969L0493 | website = eur-lex.europa.eu | accessdate = 6 February 2017 }}</ref> |- | 1998 || The automatic line was put into operation for the production of vases and decanters by [[blow-blow technology]]. |- | 2001 || The plant created the world's unique know-how by starting automatic line with so called pulled stem technology. This technology in combination with blow-blow process was for the first time in the world applied in the glassworks RONA. This success contributed significantly to the current achievements and reputation of the glassworks. |- | 2004 || International patent for barium free crystal glass.<ref name="patent"> {{Citation | inventor1-last = Šimurka | inventor1-first = Peter | inventor2-last = Vrábel | inventor2-first = Peter | inventor3-last = Petrušková | inventor3-first = Viera | inventor4-last = Liška | inventor4-first = Marek | inventor5-last = Macho | inventor5-first = Vendelín | title = Lead-free crystal glass, barium, niobium, and compounds thereof | filling-date = Oct 19, 2004 | patent-number = 285523 | publisher = The Industrial Property Office of the Slovak Republic | url = http://skpatents.com/znacka/olova | country-code = SK }}</ref> Co-organization of the conference Norbert Kreidl Memorial Conference 23–26 June 2004 Trenčín, Slovakia.<ref> {{cite book | last = Proceedings of the Norbert Kreidl Memorial Conference June 23–26, 2004 | first = | title = Building the Bridges between Glass Science and Glass Technology | publisher = Verlag der Deutschen Glastechnischen Gesellschaft, Offenbach (Germany) | year = 2004 | pages = | isbn = 3-921089-35-2 }}</ref> |- | 2007 || [[Platinum]] technology in the [[blow-blow]] forming process was applied in order to prevent so called glass line corrosion. |- | 2008 || The automatic line was put into operation for the production of mechanically shaped tumblers. |- | 2008 || The unique [[Hot Laser Technology]] (HLT) was introduced for the treatment of the product rims. It gives extra strength at the rims, significant in HORECA business, aerospace, and ship catering markets. |- | 2016 || Patenting automatic [[laser]] [[calibration]]. |- | 2016 || The first automatic product quality inspection technology was applied in the plant. |}
=== Research and development === Within scientific research activities, the company closely works with domestic and foreign institutions which do activities focused on the glass area. * Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, [[Slovak Academy of Sciences]], Bratislava, Slovakia {{cite web | last = | first = | title = IICSAS Slovakia | url = http://www.uach.sav.sk | access-date = 31 January 2017 }} * VITRUM Laugaricio, [[Glass Centre of Competence is the joint research laboratory]], Trenčín, Slovakia {{cite web | last = | first = | title = Vitrum Laugaricio - Glass Centre of Competence is the joint research laboratory | url = http://vila.tnuni.sk/index.php?id=223 | access-date = 31 January 2017 }} * Department of Glass and Ceramics, Institute of Chemical Technology, Prague, Czech Republic {{cite web | last = | first = | title = Department of Glass and Ceramics | url = http://tresen.vscht.cz/sil/en | access-date = 31 January 2017 }} * Department of Materials technologies and environmental, Faculty of Industrial Technologies Alexander Dubcek University in Puchov, Slovakia{{cite web | last = | first = | title = FPT TU Puchov, Slovakia | url = http://www.fpt.tnuni.sk | access-date = 31 January 2017 }} * [[Slovak Glass Society]], Lednicke Rovne, Slovakia{{cite web | last = | first = | title = SGS Puchov, Slovakia | url = https://sites.google.com/site/slovakglasssociety/ | access-date = 31 January 2017 }} * [[Union of Glass Industry]] of the Slovak Republic, Bratislava {{cite web | last = | first = | title = Union of Glass Industry, Slovakia | url = http://www.zvsp.sk | access-date = 31 January 2017 }}
== Museum == [[File:Kaštieľ Lednické Rovne.jpg|thumb|left|Castle-museum, Lednické Rovne, Slovakia]] The [[Slovak Glass Museum]],<ref> {{cite web | title = Slovak Glass Museum, Lednicke Rovne, Slovakia | url = http://www.muzeum.sk/?obj=muzeum&ix=sskm | website = www.muzeum.sk | accessdate = 1 February 2017 }}</ref> founded in 1988, connects the modern glassworks with its historical roots. The headquarters of the museum is a [[castle]] that was the former residence of founders of the company, reconstructed at the end of the 1980s. Today, it is used as a product showroom and administrative center, and it is used to host a biennial international glass symposium.
The history of the company's production at Lednické Rovne is documented by various collections, saved in deposits of galleries and museums such as [[Slovak National Museum]] - Historical Museum in Bratislava,<ref> {{cite web | title = Slovak National Museum, Bratislava, Slovakia | url = http://www.snm.sk/?home | website = www.snm.sk | accessdate = 1 February 2017 }}</ref> [[Central Slovakia Museum]] in Banská Bystrica,<ref> {{cite web | title = Central Slovakia Museum, Banská Bystrica, Slovakia | url = http://www.ssmuzeum.sk/english/default.htm | website = www.ssmuzeum.sk | accessdate = 1 February 2017 }}</ref> [[Slovak National Museum]] - Ethnographical museum in Martin,<ref> {{cite web |title= Slovak National Museum, Martin, Slovakia | url = http://www.snm.sk/?home | website = www.snm.sk | accessdate = 1 February 2017 }}</ref> [[Slovak National Gallery]] in Bratislava,<ref> {{cite web | title = Slovak National Gallery, Bratislava, Slovakia | url = http://www.sng.sk/en | website = www.sng.sk | accessdate = 1 February 2017 }}</ref> [[Museum of Decorative Arts in Prague|Museum of Decorative Arts]] in Prague,<ref> {{cite web | title = Museum of Decorative Arts, Prague, Czech Republic | url = http://www.upm.cz/index.php?language=en | website = www.upm.cz | accessdate = 1 February 2017 }}</ref> and [[Corning Museum of Glass]] in New York.<ref> {{cite web | title = Corning Museum of Glass, NYC | url = http://www.cmog.org/search/site/rona | website = www.cmog.org | accessdate = 1 February 2017 }}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=August 2016}} {{primary sources|date=November 2017}} }}
'''Urban informatics''' refers to the study of people creating, applying and using [[information and communication technology]] and [[data]] in the context of [[cities]] and [[urban environments]]. Various definitions are available, some provided in the [[#Definitions|Definitions]] section. Urban informatics is a trans-disciplinary field of research and practice that draws on three broad domains: people, place and technology.<ref name="FothChoi2011" />
* People can refer to city residents, [[citizens]], [[community groups]], from various socio-cultural backgrounds, as well as the social dimensions of non-profit organisations and businesses. The social research domains that urban informatics draws from include [[urban sociology]], [[media studies]], [[communication studies]], [[cultural studies]], [[city planning]] and others. * Place can refer to distinct urban sites, [[Locale (geographic)|locales]] and [[habitats]], as well as to larger scale geographic entities such as [[neighbourhoods]], [[public space]], [[suburbs]], [[regions]], or peri-urban areas. The place or spatial research domains entail [[urban studies]], [[architecture]], [[urban design]], [[urban planning]], [[geography]], and others. * Technology can refer to various types of [[information and communication technology]] and [[ubiquitous computing]] / [[urban computing]] technology such as [[mobile phones]], [[wearable devices]], urban screens, media façades, [[sensors]], and other [[Internet of Things]] devices. The technology research domains span [[informatics]], [[computer science]], [[software engineering]], [[human-computer interaction]], and others.
In addition to [[geographic data]] / [[spatial data]], most common sources of data relevant to urban informatics can be divided into three broad categories: government data ([[census]] data, [[open data]], etc.); personal data ([[social media]], [[quantified self]] data, etc.), and; sensor data ([[transport]], [[surveillance]], [[CCTV]], Internet of Things devices, etc.).<ref name="kitchin2011" /><ref name="Street Computing 2012">{{cite journal|last1=Robinson|first1=Ricky|last2=Rittenbruch|first2=Markus|last3=Foth|first3=Marcus|last4=Filonik|first4=Daniel|last5=Viller|first5=Stephen|title=Street Computing: Towards an Integrated Open Data Application Programming Interface (API) for Cities|journal=Journal of Urban Technology|date=April 2012|volume=19|issue=2|pages=1–23|doi=10.1080/10630732.2012.698064}}</ref>
Although first mentions of the term date back as early as 1987, urban informatics did not emerge as a notable field of research and practice until 2006 (see [[#History|History]] section). Since then, the emergence and growing popularity of ubiquitous computing, open data and [[big data analytics]], as well as [[smart cities]] contributed to a surge in interest in urban informatics, not just from academics but also from industry and city governments seeking to explore and apply the possibilities and opportunities of urban informatics.
== Definitions ==
Many definitions of urban informatics have been published and can be found online. The descriptions provided by Townsend in his foreword and by Foth in his preface to the "Handbook of Research on Urban Informatics"<ref name="foth2009">{{cite book|last1=Foth|first1=Marcus|title=Handbook of Research on Urban Informatics: The Practice and Promise of the Real-Time City|date=2009|publisher=Information Science Reference|location=Hershey, PA|isbn=978-1-60566-152-0|url=http://eprints.qut.edu.au/13308/}}</ref> emphasize two key aspects: (1) the new possibilities (including real-time data) for both citizens and city administrations afforded by [[ubiquitous computing]], and (2) the convergence of physical and digital aspects of the city.
{{Quotation|"Urban informatics is the study, design, and practice of urban experiences across different urban contexts that are created by new opportunities of real-time, ubiquitous technology and the augmentation that mediates the physical and digital layers of people networks and urban infrastructures."|Foth, Choi, Satchell, 2011|Urban Informatics<ref name="FothChoi2011">{{cite conference|first1=Marcus|last1=Foth|first2=Jaz Hee-jeong|last2=Choi|first3=Christine|last3=Satchell|title=Urban Informatics|conference=Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW)|pages=1–8|date=2011|location=Hangzhou, China|doi=10.1145/1958824.1958826}}</ref>}}
Although closely related, Foth differentiates urban informatics from the field of [[urban computing]] by suggesting that the former focusses more on the social and human implications of technology in cities (similar to the community and social emphases of how [[community informatics]] and [[social informatics]] are defined), and the latter focusses more on technology and computing.<ref name="foth2009" /> Urban informatics emphasises the relationship between urbanity, as expressed through the many dimensions of urban life, and technology.
Later, with the increasing popularity of commercial opportunities under the label of [[smart city]] and [[big data]], subsequent definitions became narrow and limited in defining urban informatics mainly as [[big data analytics]] for efficiency and productivity gains in city contexts – unless the arts and social sciences are added to the interdisciplinary mix.<ref name="thrift">{{cite journal|last1=Thrift|first1=Nigel|title=The Promise of Urban Informatics: Some Speculations|journal=Environment and Planning A|date=2014|volume=46|issue=6|pages=1263–1266|doi=10.1068/a472c}}</ref> This specialisation within urban informatics is sometimes referred to as 'data-driven, [[Urbanism#Network-based theories|networked urbanism]]'<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kitchin|first1=Rob|title=Data-Driven, Networked Urbanism|journal=SSRN Electronic Journal|date=2015|doi=10.2139/ssrn.2641802|ssrn=2641802}}</ref> or [[urban science]].<ref name="batty">{{cite book|last1=Batty|first1=Michael|title=The New Science of Cities|date=2013|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=9780262019521|url=https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/new-science-cities}}</ref>
== History ==
One of the first occurrences of the term can be found in Mark E. Hepworth's 1987 article "The Information City",<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hepworth|first1=Mark E.|title=The Information City|journal=Cities|date=August 1987|volume=4|issue=3|pages=253–262|doi=10.1016/0264-2751(87)90033-3}}</ref> which mentions the term "urban informatics" on page 261, however, Hepworth's overall discussion is more concerned with the broader notion of "informatics planning." Considering the article pre-dates the advent of ubiquitous computing and urban computing, it does contain some visionary thoughts about major changes on the horizon brought about by [[information and communication technology]] and the impact on cities.
The Urban Informatics Research Lab was founded at [[Queensland University of Technology]] in 2006, the first research group explicitly named to reflect its dedication to the study of urban informatics.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} The first edited book on the topic, the "Handbook of Research on Urban Informatics", published in 2009.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}, brought together researchers and scholars from three broad domains: people, place, and technology, or; the social, the spatial, and the technical.
There were many precursors to this [[transdisciplinarity]] of "people, place, and technology."<ref name="FothChoi2011" /> From an [[architecture]], [[planning]] and [[design]] background, there is the work of the late [[William J. Mitchell]], Dean of the [[MIT School of Architecture and Planning]], and author of the 1995 book "City of Bits: Space, Place, and the Infobahn."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mitchell|first1=William J.|title=City of Bits: Space, Place, and the Infobahn|date=1995|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-13309-8|url=https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/city-bits}}</ref> Mitchell was influential in suggesting a profound relationship between place and technology at a time when mainstream interest was focused on the promise of the [[Information Superhighway]] and what [[Frances Cairncross]] called the "Death of Distance."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cairncross|first1=Frances|title=The Death of Distance: How the Communications Revolution will Change our Lives|date=1997|publisher=Harvard Business School Press|location=Boston, Mass.|isbn=978-0-87584-806-8}}</ref> Rather than a decline in the significance of place through services such as [[telecommuting]], [[distance education]], [[e-commerce]], the physical / tangible layers of the city started to mix with the digital layers of the internet and online communications. Aspects of this trend have been studied under the terms community informatics<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gurstein|first1=Michael|title=Community Informatics: Enabling Communities with Information and Communications Technologies|date=2000|publisher=Idea Group Publishing|location=Hershey, PA|isbn=978-1-878289-69-8}}</ref> and [[community network]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Schuler|first1=Douglas|title=Community Networks: New Community Networks: Wired for Change|date=1996|publisher=Addison-Wesley|location=Reading, Mass.|isbn=978-0-201-59553-6}}</ref>
One of the first texts that systematically examined the impact of information technologies on the spatial and social evolution of cities is Telecommunications and the City: Electronic Spaces, Urban Places,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Graham|first1=Stephen|last2=Marvin|first2=Simon|title=Telecommunications and the City: Electronic Spaces, Urban Places.|date=1995|publisher=Routledge|location=London}}</ref> by Stephen Graham and Simon Marvin. The relationship between cities and the internet was further expanded upon in a volume edited by Stephen Graham entitled "Cybercities Reader"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Graham|first1=Stephen|title=The Cybercities Reader|date=2004|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0-415-27956-7}}</ref> and by various authors in the 2006 book "Networked Neighbourhoods: The Connected Community in Context"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Purcell|first1=Patrick|title=Networked Neighbourhoods: The Connected Community in Context|date=2006|publisher=Springer|location=London|isbn=978-1-84628-267-6|url=https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9781846282676}}</ref> edited by Patrick Purcell. Additionally, contributions from architecture, design and planning scholars are contained in the 2007 journal special issue on "Space, Sociality, and Pervasive Computing"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dave|first1=Bharat|title=Space, Sociality, and Pervasive Computing|journal=Environment and Planning B: Planning and Design|date=2007|volume=34|issue=3|pages=381–382|doi=10.1068/b3403ed}}</ref> published in the journal Environment and Planning B: Planning and Design, 34(3), guest edited by the late Bharat Dave, as well as in the 2008 book "Augmented Urban Spaces: Articulating the Physical and Electronic City"<ref name="aurigi2008">{{cite book|last1=Aurigi|first1=Alessandro|last2=De Cindio|first2=Fiorella|title=Augmented Urban Spaces: Articulating the Physical and Electronic City|date=2008|publisher=Ashgate|location=Aldershot, UK|isbn=978-0-7546-7149-7}}</ref> edited by Alessandro Aurigi and Fiorella De Cindio, based on contributions to the Digital Cities 4 workshop held in conjunction with the Communities and Technologies (C&T) conference 2005 in Milan, Italy.
The first prominent and explicit use of the term urban informatics in the [[sociology]] and [[media studies]] literature appears in the 2007 special issue "Urban Informatics: Software, Cities and the New Cartographies of Knowing Capitalism"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ellison|first1=Nick|last2=Burrows|first2=Roger|last3=Parker|first3=Simon|title=Urban Informatics: Software, Cities and the New Cartographies of Knowing Capitalism|journal=Information, Communication & Society|date=December 2007|volume=10|issue=6|pages=785–788|doi=10.1080/13691180701750975}}</ref> published in the journal Information, Communication & Society, 10(6), guest edited by Ellison, Burrows, & Parker. Later on, in 2013, Burrows and Beer argued that the socio-technical transformations described by research studies conducted in the field of urban informatics give reason for sociologists more broadly to not only question epistemological and methodological norms and practices but also to rethink spatial assumptions.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Burrows|first1=Roger|last2=Beer|first2=David|editor1-last=Orton-Johnson|editor1-first=Kate|editor2-last=Prior|editor2-first=Nick|title=Digital Sociology: Critical Perspectives|chapter=Rethinking Space: Urban Informatics and the Sociological Imagination|date=2013| pages=61–78|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=London, UK|isbn=978-0-230-22283-0|doi=10.1057/9781137297792_5}}</ref>
In [[computer science]], the sub-domains of [[human-computer interaction]], ubiquitous computing, and urban computing, provided early contributions that influenced the emerging field of urban informatics. Examples include the Digital Cities workshop series (see below), Greenfield’s 2006 book "Everyware: The Dawning Age of Ubiquitous Computing"<ref>{{Cite book|title=Everyware: The Dawning Age of Ubiquitous Computing|last=Greenfield|first=Adam|publisher=New Riders|year=2006|isbn=0321384016|location=San Francisco, US|pages=|via=}}</ref> as well as the 2006 special issue "Urban Computing: Navigating Space and Context"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shklovski|first1=Irina|last2=Chang|first2=M. F.|title=Urban Computing: Navigating Space and Context|journal=Computer|date=September 2006|volume=39|issue=9|pages=36–37|doi=10.1109/MC.2006.308}}</ref> published in the IEEE journal Computer, 39(9), guest edited by Shklovski & Chang, and the 2007 special issue "Urban Computing"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kindberg|first1=Tim|last2=Chalmers|first2=Matthew|last3=Paulos|first3=Eric|title=Urban Computing|journal=IEEE Pervasive Computing|date=July 2007|volume=6|issue=3|pages=18–20|doi=10.1109/MPRV.2007.57}}</ref> published in the IEEE journal Pervasive Computing, 6(3), guest edited by Kindberg, Chalmers, & Paulos.
== Digital Cities Workshop Series ==
The Digital Cities Workshop Series started in 1999<ref name="dc1" /> and is the longest running academic workshop series that has focused on, and profoundly influenced the field of urban informatics.<ref name="foth2015" /> The first two workshops in 1999 and 2001 were both held in Kyoto, Japan, with subsequent workshops since 2003 held in conjunction with the biennial International Conference on Communities and Technologies (C&T).
Each Digital Cities workshop proceedings have become the basis for key anthologies listed below, which in turn have also been formative to a diverse set of emerging fields, including urban informatics, urban computing, smart cities, [[pervasive computing]], [[internet of things]], media architecture, urban [[interaction design]], and urban science.

== Methods ==
The diverse range of people, groups and organisations involved in urban informatics is reflective of the diversity of methods being used in its pursuit and practice. As a result, urban informatics borrows from a wide range of methodologies across the [[social sciences]], [[humanities]], [[arts]], [[design]], [[architecture]], [[planning]] (including [[geographic information systems]]), and [[technology]] (in particular [[computer science]], pervasive computing, and ubiquitous computing), and applies those to the urban domain. Examples include:
* [[action research]] and [[participatory action research]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hearn|first1=Greg|last2=Tacchi|first2=Jo|last3=Foth|first3=Marcus|last4=Lennie|first4=June|title=Action Research and New Media: Concepts, Methods, and Cases|date=2009|publisher=Hampton Press|location=Cresskill, NJ|isbn=978-1-57273-866-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Foth|first1=Marcus|last2=Brynskov|first2=Martin|editor1-last=Gordon|editor1-first=Eric|editor2-last=Mihailidis|editor2-first=Paul|title=Civic Media: Technology, Design, Practice|chapter=Participatory Action Research for Civic Engagement|date=2016|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-03427-2|pages=563–580}}</ref> * [[big data analytics]] and [[urban science]]<ref name="batty" /> * [[critical theory]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Satchell|first1=Christine|title=Cultural Theory and Design: Identifying Trends by Looking at the Action in the Periphery|journal=ACM interactions|date=1 November 2008|volume=15|issue=6|pages=23|doi=10.1145/1409040.1409046}}</ref> * [[cultural mapping]] * [[grounded theory]] * [[interaction design]] * [[participatory design]] * [[spatial analysis]] including urban modelling, complex urban systems analysis, [[geographic information systems]], [[space syntax]] analysis * [[user-centred design]]
